results.title: Nests in the bush
results.brief_description: A classroom film for young children on how different Australian birds build and conceal their nests and rear their young. Yellow robin, wren, loterill, honey-eater and wagtail are among those seen.
results.description: A classroom film for young children on how different Australian birds build and conceal their nests and rear their young. Yellow robin, wren, loterill, honey-eater and wagtail are among those seen.

results.title: Nest Web Cocoon
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media
results.brief_description: A nature study film showing a bird (bottle-swallow) nesting, a spider (Golden Orb) building its web, and a caterpillar (gum emperor moth) making a cocoon. No narration.
results.description: A nature study film showing a bird (bottle-swallow) nesting, a spider (Golden Orb) building its web, and a caterpillar (gum emperor moth) making a cocoon. No narration.

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Nest of Tens
results.brief_description: ‘Nest of tens’ is comprised of four alternating stories which reveal mundane yet personal methods of control. These systems are derived from intuitive sources. Children and a retarded adult operate control panels made out of paper, lists, monsters and their own bodies. ‘A young boy, home alone, performing a bizarre ritual with a baby; an uneasy, aborted sexual flirtation between a teenage babysitter and an older man; an airport lounge encounter between a businesswoman (played by July) and a young girl. Linked by a lecturer enumerating phobias in a quasi-academic seminar, these three perverse, unnerving scenarios involving children and adults provide authentic glimpses into the queasy strangeness that lies behind the everyday’. New York Video Festival, 2000.

results.title: Nervous systems in animals
results.brief_description: All living organisms respond to stimuli and even uni-cellular animals can make such reactions although their means of co-ordination are not known. Examining the neuron structure of multi-cellular hydra, planarians, annelids, various insects, fish, birds, amphibians and mammals, their nervous systems are exposed by micro-photography and dissection.
results.description: All living organisms respond to stimuli and even uni-cellular animals can make such reactions although their means of co-ordination are not known. results.title: Nervous system. - 3rd. edition.
results.brief_description: Includes some of the first micrographs ever to show nerve cells in the act of sending and receiving impulses. Explains the complex physiology of the central and peripheral nervous systems and their parts. Identifies certain foods and drugs that have a variety of effects on the nervous system.

results.title: Nervous system in man
results.brief_description: Shows interlocking of effects of endocrine and nervous systems. Illustrates the types of nerve cells, and processes of impulse transmission. Discusses the diseases of the nervous system. From the Human Physiology Series.

results.title: Nerve centre
results.creator_credit: Jack Smith and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Body”.
Designed for 11 to 14 year olds, the film illustrates the human brain and nerves, using resources not available in the classroom or school laboratory. Uses clinical techniques, anatomical models and preparations selected to demonstrate body functions.

results.title: Nerida Anderson, 1939
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Bob Weis, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Three of a series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women at different periods in time. Set in 1939, this episode examines attempts by Nerida Anderson and her family to improve conditions on the Aboriginal Reserve where they live. Such attempts and displays of independence outrage the manager. He has Nerida and her family tried for treason. Realising a no-win situation, the entire population of the reserve pack their belongings and leave.
